A Kassadari alternative to the common railgun. The Styrix fires a 3-round burst of high-velocity projectiles with decent accuracy, that are commonly timed to cover the impact window of high-explosive weaponry to suppress shields. The impactor rounds are also loaded with a micro warhead that can cause additional damage if the round manages to pierce the outer layers of armor.
A medium railcannon firing an armor-piercing dual warhead projectile featuring an experimental temporal fragmentation warhead.

Reliable and effective, the Armiger is a medium-caliber cannon that prioritizes projectile velocity and range over sheer firepower, making for a weapon that pairs well with high-velocity kinetic armaments.
An integrated arc-discharge weapon, rapidly discharging bolts of energy to any enemies within its targeting cone. Effective against all targets, it can also function as a point-defense weapon.
A twin-linked heavy cannon with good striking power. Its secondary plasma burst warhead grants it slightly improved performance against shields.

Designed to supplement Volkite-type PD weapons against harder targets, this micro-railgun fires hypervelocity kinetic slugs to intercept incoming missiles and strikecraft. Being particularly effective against shielded fighters, it truly shines when paired with Volkite-class PD solutions as intended.

Originally designed for shipbreaking operations, these industrial fusion torches have found great popularity amongst pirates for their destructive potential when sufficiently modified. While their range is severely limited, the damage potential and electromagnetic interference of the bluehot flame makes it a terrifying weapon on fast attack ships.
Designed for mining operations, this lance was never intended for combat use, but is no less effective at cutting apart spaceships than any other high-powered directed energy beam.
A heavy plasma cannon of unknown origin. Boasting solid firepower and fast projectiles, it has a strong general purpose profile.
A medium energy blaster of unknown origin. A versatile and flexible weapon that is effective against most targets.

A small energy beam emitter of unknown origin. Fires a powerful and high-impact beam that is highly effective against small targets. While potent as a PD weapon, it lacks the internal targeting systems to act as a PD weapon without an external PD system.

An icon of pirate hubris, the Deathgaze is a heavily modified asteroid mining laser, supercharged to dangerous levels and about as likely to blow out the flux grid of whatever ship it is mounted on with a feedback spike as it is to cut its prey apart. When it functions, however, it does so quite well and to devastating effect.

Fully integrated and supplied by the ship's reactor, this variant of the Deathgaze features an enhanced capacitor charge rate over its modular cousin.

An icon of pirate hubris, the Deathgaze is a heavily modified asteroid mining laser, supercharged to dangerous levels and about as likely to blow out the flux grid of whatever ship it is mounted on with a feedback spike as it is to cut its prey apart. When it functions, however, it does so quite well and to devastating effect.

Based on the hellbore, this upscaled heavy cannon is fully integrated into the ship's hull and outfitted with numerous recoil stabilizers to prevent it from ripping the ship apart when firing. Despite the major upscaling, its actual performance isn't that much superior to a standard hellbore, but the psychological impact of such a massive weapon pointing at a lightly-armored freighter is exceedingly useful in piracy actions.

Designed for long-range engagements, the Pendragon is a unique MIRV launcher that utilizes a fast but barely maneuverable carrier missile to deliver a swarm of agile micromissiles into effective range.

A somewhat outdated design, the Efreet fires a constant barrage of kinetic impact shells over long ranges. While generally effective, the simple design lacks adequate recoil compensation for its massive propelling charge and suffers from subpar projectile velocity and bad accuracy during extended firing.

Going back to an antiquated design, this unique beam weapon uses a synthetic crystal as focus for a powerful sustained directed energy beam. While powerful in and of itself, the weapon can operate at an increased powerlevel when the mounting ship's flux grid is under heavy load, presumably due to the unique properties of its focus crystal.

A bulky energy weapon from an early epoch, the TPC is built directly into the Castigator's hull and provides overwhelming frontal firepower.

Designed before modular energy weapons were universally trusted by Domain naval architects, this weapon was coded into the Onslaught's blueprint because no other hull of the time was large enough or had reactors capable of generating the requisite power.

This particular variant was later adapted to the Castigator chassis and while it possesses the same firepower as those used on an Onslaught, the more limited power supply of the smaller Castigator limits its charge capacity.

Like many Kassadari weapons, the Gardas is a design never truly intended for mass production. A heavily overengineered railcannon firing an armor-piercing round with a temporal fragmentation warhead, this massive weapon is highly effective against armor and causality itself, but lacks the technological refinement of a mainline combat weapon.
An integrated torpedo tube for hammer-class torpedoes. Equipped with an autoloader for extended engagements.

A massive artillery cannon predating the era of modular weaponry, the Fafnir was designed specifically for the Nibelung-class and is an early ancestor of the Mjolnir. The weapon fires a long-range shell with a singularity warhead that is effective against all targets and the fully integrated nature of the weapon makes it more flux-efficient than the contemporary Mjolnir. Few of these weapons can still be found as the majority of remaining Nibelung-class battleships have since been refitted to accommodate modular weaponry, yet a few captains out there held on to these mighty weapons.
An integrated missile battery firing 5 agile multi-purpose missiles for use against most targets.
An integrated missile battery firing 5 agile multi-purpose missiles for use against most targets.
Fighter-grade Volkite variant
Hypercharged ion blaster mounted on the Valacor. The high rate of fire makes it an excellent suppression weapon.

A modification of the Hekaton-class torpedo. The primary high-explosive warhead has been downscaled to accommodate guidance systems and the required thrusters. The resulting weapon still packs a punch, but sacrifices speed and damage for improved accuracy.

A versatile twin cannon firing voidburst charges. Effective against most targets and capable of substituting as point-defense weapon, the Ronka is a true all-rounder, but fails to excel at any particular role.

A pair of superheavy cannons in a twin mount, the Anumis fires accurate high-explosive rounds equipped with a miniaturized version of the Hekaton's signature secondary plasma burst warhead, granting it slightly improved performance against shields.

A light anti-armor weapon with extended range thanks to an advanced trajectory correction system. Sadly this system comes at the cost of projectile velocity, limiting the weapon's effectiveness against more nimble targets.

A massive spinal hyperrail cannon that served as an early prototype for what is now the Gardas. Unlike the later modular production versions, the Gleipnir is equipped with two capacitor banks and can fire both kinetic impactor rounds and high-explosive fracture warheads, allowing for a devastating double-tap with a shield-breaking shot followed by an armor-breaker. The weapon however suffers from a high power demand, requiring the ship's assault mode to be fully active in order to fire.

An advanced suppression weapon firing drone-guided ionizing charges. Due to the small scale of the drones their ammo supply is virtually unlimited. This heavier variant is unique to the Ristreza and boasts improved range over modular variants.
The core of the Cuchulainn is a massive tachyon beam projector with impressive output, but suffering from a difficult to maintain design.
An advanced suppression weapon firing drone-guided ionizing charges. Due to the small scale of the drones their ammo supply is virtually unlimited.

While generally identical to the Gleipnir found on a standard Ristreza, this model had its secondary capacitor bank and alternate ammunition storage units removed to make room for the two Fountainfall arrays. It now serves primarily as anti-shield weapon to supplement the heavy missile barrages.
One of two massive VLS missile arrays built into this variant of the Ristreza, capable of saturating large sections of battlespace with micromissiles.
One of two massive VLS missile arrays built into this variant of the Ristreza, capable of saturating large sections of battlespace with micromissiles.

A large pair of micromissile batteries, designed to overwhelm point-defense systems through sheer volume. While the individual missiles aren't exceptionally powerful against larger vessels, they pose a deadly threat to smaller targets.
A medium-sized micromissile battery. Quite effective at saturating point-defense systems for a weapon of its size and deadly to smaller ships.
An integrated PD solution mounted just above the Fountainfall arrays to compensate for the lack of standard small mounts.
A large launcher for Hekaton-class torpedoes. Features a fast reloading mechanism to allow for the firing of torpedoes in rapid succession and ample ammunition capacity.
An old design by Kassadari standards, the Praxus is a fairly conventional rotary cannon. Very effective against shields.

The result of efforts to further upscale the ever-reliable Magaera, the Alteria is the Kassadari main general-purpose kinetic option for large weapon mounts. Virtually every aspect of the weapon has been upscaled from its smaller cousin, firing a larger, heavier impactor round with devastating effectiveness against shields.

Based on the Titanomachy, this beam weapon has been integrated with the hull of the Numistri. Replacing the Gleipnir of a standard Ristreza, it now operates in a burst rather than sustained fire, and can only be brought to bear when the vessel’s assault systems are active. While already potent on paper, in practice it tends to outperform even the intended properties, as the immense power throughput causes the focus crystal to near-constantly fire off arcs of violent energy capable of damaging and frying weapons and engines alike.

A surprisingly sophisticated weapon for something designed by apparent pirates, the Balor is an advanced smart weapon firing self-propelled shells with limited tracking ability. Despite low shell velocity, these tracking capabilities make the weapon extremely accurate at long range.
A medium-sized smartgun of the Legio Infernalis. Possessing excellent range, accuracy and rate of fire, it is only held back by its low projectile velocity and subpar armor penetration capability.
The Goll fires a spread of overcharge spikes that lack any real direct damage potential, but discharge a powerful electromagnetic pulse on impact.
Firing small caliber high-velocity kinetic rounds from its 4 barrels, the Conand is exceptionally efficient against shields, but lacks any kind of armor penetration ability.
A burst-fire variant of the Goll designed to cripple most ships in a single burst in advance of boarding actions.
A massive array of fountain-type micromissile tubes built into the Scathach's bow, capable of firing enough missiles to overwhelm all but the mightiest of PD arrays.
A heavy triple-barrel turret integral to the Metafalica. Linked to its variable ammo system, it can adapt to any situation.

The result of scaling up an autocannon to excessive size and loading it with high-explosive ammunition. While limited by relatively short range, the sheer firepower and armor-breaking potential makes this weapon fairly effective.
A massive omnidirectional beam emitter central to the Songbird's design. Functioning both as point-defense and anti-ship weapon, it gives the Songbird excellent flexibility in combat.

Officially called the Parallel Energized Particle Pulse Array, this large energy weapon fires diffuse but heavily ionized projectiles. While struggling to deal effective damage against shields or armor, it can effectively suppress ship weapons and engines.
An integrated torpedo tube for Atropos-class torpedoes. Equipped with an autoloader.
"I do not know how they managed to scale up what is essentially an Antimatter Blaster to this level of output, but if this thing ever malfunctions, I want to be in a different constellation."
"Whatever you do, stay clear of whatever general area that lightning gun is aiming at. Good luck trying to tell an electric charge of that scale what an IFF is."
"I heard the guys on deck 4 still have some numb limbs because gunnery couldn't stop themselves from keeping that new gun firing on full tilt. Got chewed out by the FO for that one."

An early variant graviton beam, built into the Flagellator's hull. While its damage output is laughable at best, it primarily serves as interdiction device to slow down smaller ships and hinder their movement.

A modified Hammer Barrage launcher built into the ship's hull and attached to an improvised autoloader. While this setup negates the usual long-term ammunition limitations, it's capacity for ready-to-fire torpedoes is reduced.

An obscure offspring of the PEPPA, the Pastella Blaster had its pulse emitter core heavily modified to massively increase the power output. The result is an exceedingly potent weapon that fires a burst of powerful energy blasts at extremely short ranges. While technically quite efficient, the burst still generates an excessive amount of flux, too much to handle for many ships and interferences limit the number of these weapons that can be effectively mounted on a single hull.

"I have no idea what that gun is even firing, but it fucks up shields real good. Best part though? I've got a buddy in logistics and he told me they don't even know where it gets the ammo from. Some nanoforge bullshit I swear."

The insane result of bundling three naval rifles into a rotary cannon, the Breaker can fire large caliber anti-armor shells at a terrifying rate. Practicality may be debated, but a rotary weapon of this scale is valuable for psychological impact alone.

Heavy anti-armor shells, a massive propellant charge and horribly undersized recoil dampeners are the three components that define the Aetnos. A single salvo from this weapon can cause remarkable damage to even heavily armored ships, if it can manage to hit, that is.

While technically an antiquated design, this particular type of plasma cannon has seen countless revisions over the ages. With high alpha damage and a solid output, it has managed to stay relevant for decades of technological progress.
Old but reliable, this plasma weapon variant boasts excellent striking power for a weapon of its size.

Attempts to downscale thermal pulse weaponry are about as old as the original Thermal Pulse Cannon itself, but rarely found much success. The Thermal Pulse Blaster was a partial success, at least, in that it allowed for the use of an articulated emitter linked to a ship-internal power source. This particular example seems to have been found in some old Hegemony spare part storage facility and jury-rigged to the TPC-internals that were left in the hull in the Legio conversion process.

With a high rate of fire and fast ionized shells, the Vesuvio has the potential to be terrifying to most vessels, but is held back by its below average range and high flux overhead.

Supposedly designed to supplant the Mk.IX Autocannon, this fast-cycling magnetic accelerator cannon is really just an example of a solution in search of a problem. While the EMP capabilities and excellent output are surely nice attributes, the weapon it was meant to replace just continues to prove that simplicity of design will often triumph.
An integrated launch tube for Hammer-type torpedoes, feeding from an internal reserve at the cost of taking a short while to reload after firing.
An integrated launch tube for Sabot SRMs, feeding from an internal reserve at the cost of taking a short while to reload after firing.

The massive spinal gun of the Hel Scaith fires a large supercritical antimatter projectile with devastating destructive potential. Taking even a single hit from this weapon can cripple or destroy many ships, but the weapon's low projectile velocity limits its use to more cumbersome targets.

A weapon of last resort, the Manannan is only ever deployed in the face of equivalent escalation of firepower, an act quite unusual of Legio leadership and testament to the sheer devastating power of this weapon.
"If she is to be the all-mother, we must grant her the blade with which to defend her children until the day they can take up their own arms."

Essentially a pair of heavy mortars in a shared mounting. While otherwise unremarkable, the more spacious housing allows for better autoloaders, improving the rate of fire over that of two individual heavy mortars, and a slight increase in range.

Based on an older Domain-era variant of the Sabot SRM, this Legio-built version of the weapon uses a single submunition for enhanced performance against small craft and armor at cost of reduced total kinetic payload.

A variant of the common Plasma Cannon modified for close combat, the Hellspitter sacrifices range to greatly reduce its strain on the flux grid, allowing it to unleash a relentless barrage of plasma fire.

The workings of the modification are ultimately incredibly simple, as reducing the strength of the plasma containment field inherently makes the firing process less demanding and allows for more rapid capacitor recharge, negating the need for burst fire.
While lightweight, the Omna's missiles carry a surprisingly potent EMP warhead for their size and employ a fanning attack pattern to strike targets from multiple angles.
The dreadful AM-warhead of a Reaper-class torpedo wed to a mass resonance field generator. A weapon designed for the sole purpose of bringing down even the largest of warships.

The Sturmkanone is a venerated design within Rosenritter circles and standard on many Regalia, being regarded as a knightly weapon and often chosen over more specialized armaments for this reason alone. Based on an old and simple plasma cannon design, the weapon has been refined over centuries and boasts excellent efficiency against all kinds of targets.

A design as old as time, the Stahlhagel is a reliable rotary cannon that traces its roots back to the Elder Houses. Many variations of its basic designs have found use as anti-shield weaponry on Regalias going back to their first generation.

Combining two lower caliber Stahlhagel variants into a single turret, this Zwilling variant achieves an impressive rate of fire. While the individual projectiles are lighter and less accurate than on other variants of the weapon, it remains highly effective against shields. The weapon system's main disadvantage is its complex ammo feeder system which fails to keep up with the weapon's output without additional modifications.

Effectively a pair of Stahlhagel rotary cannons upgraded to a larger caliber in a larger mount, the Hagelsturm is a devastating suppression weapon. Powerful as it may be, however, the weapon ultimately found only limited use due to generally only being mounted on supplementary vessels as Rosenritter ship design tends to forego large mounts.

Few weapons are as simple yet effective as a heavy combat rifle. Loaded with heavy high-explosive rounds, the Panzerfaust performs true to its name, delivering a devastating punch to even the heaviest armor. Developed specifically for the Glanzwurf Regalia, this advanced pulse blaster was based on the common pulse laser, but upgraded with a dual chamber system and auxiliary capacitor banks that allow it to switch to a powerful plasma blast mode similar to the Sturmkanone. A long-range voidburst cannon designed specifically for the escort configuration of the Glanzwurf Regalia. Effective against most targets and capable of serving as point-defense weapon, it is ideal for its intended role.

One of the few Rosenritter weapons developed primarily for use on regular warships rather than Regalia, the Kriegsmesser is a heavy anti-ship missile with a volatile plasma warhead. The multiple secondary explosions caused on impact are said to be particularly pleasant to observe.

text1: The last bastion of civilization in the Lethia system, Kassadar is a cold and unfriendly world to most of its inhabitants, but even from space you can see the few massive hive cities, that in their upper levels house the old nobility of the Great Houses. Warships bearing the orange stripes of the Kassadari navy orbit the planet, their temporal systems distorting space around them in an unwelcoming display of power.
text3: Before you lies the remnant of the Great Houses' ambitions, its black spires reminiscing the lost glory of what was once set to become a powerful local polity. As the planet draws nearer, you can't help but feel a strange nostalgia for the age of the Domain and the prosperity it once brought.

text1: Evergreen jungles cover the entirety of Heridal, with the exception of large, now abandoned, agricultural zones that can be seen from orbit. It seems strange that such a world now lies abandoned, but the colony was still too early in its development when the collapse cut off the flow of much-needed supplies. With its untapped riches however, it is only a matter of time till the Kassadari will reclaim this world.

The molten hellscape of Atanor is no place for any human to live, but the planet's rich mineral deposits once fueled the Kassadari infrastructure. Now it lies abandoned, its mines patiently waiting for a time the Kassadari people may return.
Once the lifeline supplying the Lethia system with the materials needed to build and expand its three colonies, the gate has fallen inactive and plunged the system into chaos and despair.

Host to a considerable slave population, Melchiresa serves to supply the war factories of Lucifron with the raw materials required. The prospect of ending up in this hellish place has driven many a merchant captain to fight to their death in face of a Legio attack.
text3: Like a white marble the planet lies before you on the viewscreen, almost beautiful to behold. For a moment you forget the horrors its population has been subjected to under Legio occupation.

text1: The presumed headquarters of the Legio Infernalis are buried deep into the surface of Lucifron. The toxic atmosphere of this world has bred a hardened population that eagerly enters the Legio's service in hopes of claiming a greener world for themselves.
text3: Just seeing the toxic atmosphere of the planet, you can almost smell the sulphurous stench that you know permeates every corner of Lucifron and look forward to your departure already.

text1: A small military outpost at the edge of the system. Extensively used as a training facility for the crews of some of the more advanced Legio vessels.
text3: The heavily armed station is barely visible before the red nebula, coated in black metal, its many armaments on full display. In the far distance behind it you behold the black hole at the heart of the system. You have yet to truly decide which of the two is more frightening to behold.

text1:
Pirate groups are aplenty in the post-collapse sector, so it is of little surprise in retrospect that the ambitious Legio Infernalis was seen as just one of many for a great many years. Often better equipped than their contemporaries, they were nonetheless often overlooked due to laying relatively low and greater events keeping the attention of the Sector's primary powers. While Loke ran rampant across the sector, the Legio stuck to its backwater worlds at the very edge of the core. When the AI wars raged, few paid attention to Legio raids on Tri-Tachyon research facilities, and when they did, most appreciated the acts against the power-hungry corporation.

When the dust of the AI wars settled, curious eyes finally cared to take a closer look at the shadowy pirate group which had persisted for longer than one would expected from a band of murderers and thieves. Legio fleets had recently become fighting forces of concerning power and the infamous Rubicon system had made a name for itself as a place of no return among independent starfarers.

The Legio's true ambitions remain hidden to this day, but as more of the brighter minds in the sector have made efforts to dig deeper, one name in particular has surfaced on more occasions than coincidence would permit: The Nightwatch.
